Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Perioperative Warming Strategies

Trial_Design.evidence: The sample size was calculated to ensure adequate power.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adult surgical patients meeting specific eligibility criteria.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving forced air warming (FAW) or the control group receiving passive warming methods.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of various warming strategies.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the maintenance of core body temperature, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the FAW group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the FAW group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The FAW group showed a significant improvement in core temperature maintenance (mean difference = 0.5°C, 95% CI 0.3 to 0.7; p < 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the FAW group and 1% of the control group, with mild severity.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institute of Health.
